summary: In this chapter, the significance of making one's superiors feel superior is emphasized. It warns against the dangers of displaying one's own brilliance too openly, which can provoke insecurity in those in power. Through the example of Nicolas Fouquet and Louis XIV, it highlights that excessive showiness can lead to one's downfall. Similarly, Galileo's cunning approach in flattering the Medicis demonstrates the strategic importance of making others feel great. The chapter concludes with suggestions on how to navigate power dynamics without outshining those above you, maintaining their esteem while subtly advancing your own position.

slides.section_body: To effectively climb the hierarchy, it’s crucial to allow those above you to feel comfortably superior. This conduct fosters loyalty and respect while protecting you from their insecurities. Never display your talents too overtly or risk inspiring fear instead of admiration.
slides.quote: Make your masters appear more brilliant than they are and you will attain the heights of power.

slides.section_body: Fouquet’s extravagant party meant to honor Louis XIV ultimately led to his ruin. Instead of securing his position, it provoked the king’s jealousy and insecurity, demonstrating how brilliance can backfire when not carefully managed.
slides.quote: By the time the party ended, he was at the bottom.

slides.section_body: Louis XIV's pride made him intolerant of anyone who overshadowed him. After Fouquet’s party, the king replaced him with the more subdued Colbert, illustrating the risk of making the master feel insecure.
slides.quote: Each new spectacle made it seem to Louis that his friends were more charmed by Fouquet than by him.

slides.section_body: Galileo learned to flatter the Medicis, transforming his discoveries into glory for them. By focusing solely on one patron, he secured a steady position and wealth, exemplifying how aligning with a master's glory can lead to personal success.
slides.quote: Galileo gave the Medicis infinitely more glory.

slides.section_body: Those in power desire to feel superior. To thrive, you must navigate this delicate balance, making masters feel wiser and more competent while subtly reinforcing your own influence.
slides.quote: All masters want to appear more brilliant than other people.

slides.section_body: Outshining someone may not only bring resentment but could also endanger your position. The risks are higher with insecure individuals who may not react favorably to your success.
slides.quote: Outshining the master is perhaps the worst mistake of all.

slides.section_body: Prince Astorre Manfredi's natural charm led to envy from Cesare Borgia, resulting in his tragic end. His presence alone overshadowed Borgia, teaching the importance of awareness of those in power.
slides.quote: The presence of strong talents can provoke dangerous responses from the insecure.

slides.section_body: Never take your position for granted. Favors can quickly turn to contempt if the master feels challenged or if you display a lack of humility regarding your status.
slides.quote: Never let any favors you receive go to your head.

slides.section_body: Mastering the art of discreet flattery can ensure you remain in favor. Be tactful; make it appear that your ideas are an extension of your master’s while subtly elevating your own status.
slides.quote: Perception is key; make them believe they shine brighter.

slides.section_body: Choosing the right moments to outshine your superior can turn weaknesses into opportunities if done wisely. Monitor their strength and act strategically to navigate power dynamics effectively.
slides.quote: Gauge your master’s strength; outsmart him discreetly when the time is right.
